docs.lead_paragraph: IMAGINE, for a moment, that you are Joe Widgetmaker, chief executive of a small family-owned company. You hire a blind person, you install Braille buttons in the elevator. You hire a paraplegic, you build a ramp and lower the water fountain. You do this because you are a nice guy. Not to mention that Federal law requires it. But what if your foreman is depressed and sleepless and can't show up on time to get the assembly line rolling? What if your clerk has obsessive-compulsive disorder and persists in addressing the same envelope 100 times?

headline.main: Breaks for Mental Illness: Just What the Government Ordered

docs.abstract: Article discusses implications of EEOC order that employers may not discriminate against mentally-ill workers or job applicants, and must take 'reasonable steps' to accommodate workers with psychiatric or emotional problems; such accommodations could range from flexible schedule for anxious people to window space for person depressed by lack of light to quiet spot for schizophrenics; small-business owners see great potential for abuse, if, for instance, workers with 'phobia' about traffic come in late or 'sex addicts' also have to be accommodated (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: FILL out the one-page application form, and drop it off at the admissions office. Ask your high school to send a copy of your transcript -- you need not worry about the D you got in chemistry -- and answer some questions about your health. Then, presto: you are admitted to Brookdale Community College, a two-year institution with 28 programs to choose from and a pastoral campus here just off the Garden State Parkway. You can cover the cost -- about $2,100 a year for a full-time student -- with a loan small enough to pay off in a few years. You can start classes tomorrow and continue indefinitely, keeping a full-time job if you must. You can take specialized courses to prepare for a certain career, or stick with the liberal arts and mull your options.
docs.abstract: New Jersey's 19 community colleges are popular choice for New Jersey students because they are inexpensive and accessible; more than 127,000 New Jerseyans are working toward degrees at community colleges this year, representing 40 percent of undergraduates at all of state's public and private institutions; their open-admissions policy guarantees space to anyone with high school diploma; photos; chart (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: Kathleen Taylor Hines, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Bernard G. Hines Jr. of Tuscaloosa, Ala., was married there yesterday to David Ernest Roth, the son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert F. Roth of New York. The Rev. Charles M. Durham performed the ceremony at the First Presbyterian Church. Mrs. Roth, 26, was until recently an account executive for Premier Marketing, a health-care advertising agency in Tuscaloosa. She graduated from the University of Alabama. The bride's mother, Sally R. Hines, is an agent and the bride's father is the office manager for the State Farm Insurance Company in Tuscaloosa.

docs.lead_paragraph: The economics of organ transplantation are too disconcerting to dismiss with the flippant remark that ''those without coverage don't make the cut.'' There are now more than 40 million Americans who do not have health insurance. In this brave new world of managed care, even some people who think that they have coverage can find that their H.M.O. may not authorize a transplant or may delay authorization until it is too late. Robert J. Yaes, M.D. Gaithersburg, Md.

headline.main: Carol Palumbo Waits for Her Heart

docs.abstract: Letter by Dr Robert J Yaes on Charles Siebert's April 13 article on heart transplants that followed patient Carol Palumbo through procedure at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center (S)ÿ

docs.lead_paragraph: President Clinton agreed on Friday to a compromise plan with Republicans to balance the Federal budget by 2002. Whether the plan will be enacted as written remains unclear, and murkier still is the question of whether it would actually eliminate the deficit in five years. But as a political document, the agreement was quite an accomplishment, encompassing compromises on sweeping ideological issues like the size and role of the Government (it will get slightly smaller) and on specific programs.

headline.main: A Compromise for 2002: Balancing the Federal Budget

docs.abstract: Agreement between Pres Clinton and Republican leaders on balancing Federal budget by 2005 noted (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: America's unemployment rate dropped in April below 5 percent, a level not seen since December 1973, when Richard M. Nixon was President, the Government reported today. A startling three-tenths of a point decline in the jobless rate pushed it down to 4.9 percent, as factories recorded a new peak in overtime hours and the economy continued to advance at a healthy pace. While there were signs that the rapid economic growth of recent months was slowing, the evidence of further gains on the job front convinced many economists that the Federal Reserve remained on track to raise interest rates at least one more time, probably at its next meeting on May 20.
docs.abstract: US unemployment rate dropped to 4.9 percent in April, lowest level since December 1973; startling three-tenths of a point decline comes as factories record new peak in overtime hours and economy continues to advance at healthy pace; Pres Clinton hails strongest economy in generation; annual growth rate of 5.6 percent for first three months of year also cited; nation is now enjoying rare combination of low unemployment and low inflation; graphs; stock market, unfazed, ends week with strong gains; jobless ranks dwindled by 430,000, benefiting all demographic groups, but especially adult women (4.4 percent jobless) and blacks (9.8 percent) (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The economic windfall that put billions of additional dollars into the budget pot allowed negotiators today to soften the impact of their proposed cutbacks in Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security. The last-minute revisions went far to assuage the concerns of the elderly, whose lobbyists said tonight that the agreement reached by President Clinton and Congressional Republicans had improved substantially in the last 36 hours and was now more acceptable to them.

headline.main: Budget Negotiators Soften Impact of Cuts for Elderly

docs.abstract: Economic windfall that put billions of additional dollars into budget pot allows negotiators to soften impact of their proposed cutbacks in Medicare, Medicaid and Social Security; changes described; graphs show increases in Medicaid and Medicare spending, 1967-97 fiscal years (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Clinton Administration reached agreement with the Republican leadership today on a plan to balance the Federal budget in five years, using a last-minute financial windfall to help forge a deal that could alter the nation's economic and political landscape. The pact came after years of bitter partisan wrangling, months of intense negotiations and several hours of high drama in which an astounding piece of news -- that deficits over the next five years were likely to be $225 billion lower than the Republicans had previously projected -- provided the final impetus to completing the deal.

headline.main: AFTER YEARS OF WRANGLING, ACCORD IS REACHED ON PLAN TO BALANCE BUDGET BY 2002

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton reaches agreement with Republican leadership on plan to balance Federal budget in five years; pact, following years of bitter partisan wrangling and months of intense negotiations, is completed with help of last-minute news that deficits in next five years are likely to be $225 billion lower than Republicans had projected; Clinton gets money for education, health insurance for children and Medicare; Republicans get long-sought cuts in capital gains and other taxes, cuts in overall domestic spending and start on curbing Medicare and other entitlements; Clinton and Sen leader Trent Lott praise deal; photos of Lott and Repr Bill Archer; Republicans can now take home austerity package that insulates them from Democratic attack; highlights; Clinton also wins restoration of welfare benefits for legal immigrants and expansion of student loan and Head Start programs; deal is made possible after Congressional Budget Office slashes deficit projections, enabling negotiators to take out sensitive elements such as Social Security cost-of-living increases (M)
docs.snippet: The Clinton Administration reached agreement with the Republican leadership today on a plan to balance the Federal budget in five years, using a last-minute financial windfall to help forge a deal that could alter the nation's economic and political...

docs.lead_paragraph: Clinton and Republicans Agree to Balance Budget The Clinton Administration and the Republican leadership agreed to balance the Federal budget in five years. Facilitating the deal, which could alter the nation's economic and political landscape, was a decision by the Congressional Budget Office to slash its deficit estimates for coming years.

docs.lead_paragraph: On Thursday evening, with a budget deal imminent, Bill Clinton was once again being accused of treason by the liberal wing of his party. In an angry two-and-a-half-hour session, Democrat after Democrat from the House told the President's chief of staff, Erskine B. Bowles, of their many problems with an agreement that they believed would undercut some of their party's basic principles.

headline.main: Despite Angry Colleagues, Clinton Unites His Party

docs.abstract: Pres Clinton is able to subdue some angry Democrats who feel that budget agreement with Republicans would undercut some of Democratic Party's basic principles, and unify his party; but some Democrats say that despite agreement, they feel they were largely shut out of budget negotiating process, leaving them feeling bruised and mistrustful of Clinton; photo of Clinton and Sen Tom Daschle of South Dakota, minority leader (M)
